item.title: Report E-2024090401
item.description:
Report E-2024090401

Identified by scraper @ 2024-09-22T09:13:18+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-09-16
  • City: HENDERSON
  • State: CO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At Veolia's ten-day facility in Henderson, CO, staff identified a leaking trailer in the parking lot storage area. Upon discovery, the trailer was promptly relocated to a loading dock for further inspection and handling. During the offloading process, it was determined that a drum within the trailer had sustained damage. Specifically, a nail puncture had created a pinhole leak at the bottom of the drum. As a result of this damage, approximately one gallon of liquid had escaped. Upon conducting a thorough investigation into the incident, the root cause of the leak was identified. It was discovered that the drum had been compromised due to a structural issue with its supporting pallet. Specifically, a nail was found to be protruding from the pallet on which the drum had been placed. This protruding nail had punctured the bottom of the drum during transit or handling, creating the pinhole leak that led to the subsequent fluid release. Immediate action was taken to address the situation. The compromised drum was placed into an overpack container to prevent any additional leakage. Concurrently, a thorough clean-up operation was conducted to remove all spilled liquid from the affected area, ensuring no residual contamination remained.

  • Description: A pallet of bags of UN3378 arrived damaged to service center 302. The service center manager advised that a pallet was jammed up into the bottom bag of the Pro, and when the pallet was removed it was discovered that it had punctured a bag on the bottom layer and torn a bag on the second layer. The p uncture to the bottom bag had left a small pile, but nothing seemed to have spilled from the bag with the tear above it. CURA was contacted for remediation.

item.title: Report X-2024091113
item.description:
Report X-2024091113

Identified by scraper @ 2024-09-22T09:13:18+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-09-13
  • City: MEMPHIS
  • State: TN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 9/12/2024 at approximately 2315, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 749919 at the hub facility in Memphis, reporting a dangerous goods spill. The shipment consisted of 2 metal cans of paint packaged in one fiberboard box. The shipment was discovered displaying stains, prompting further investigation, which resulted in confirmation of spillage. One of the can showed evidence of paint spilling inside of the plastic closure. The shipment was placed in a salvage drum and is being held, awaitng an amended Shipper' s Declaration for further transport.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: RESPONDER WAS CALLED TO PACKAGE LEAKING WHITE POWDER ON SORT PLATFORM. RESPONDER RESPONDED IN FULL PPE, CART, AND MOST RECENT DECISION TREE. PACKAGE WAS TAKEN TO DMP TO BE PROCESSED. EXTERIOR OF PACKAGE CONTAINED LIMITED QUANTITY DIAMOND LABEL, AND DIRECTIONAL ARROWS. PLASTIC PAIL INSIDE OF THE BOX CONTAINED YELLOW 5.1 OXIDIZER DIAMOND LABEL. MANAGEMENT WAS NOTIFIED. RESPONDER PROCESSED AND DISPOSED OF ACCORDING TO APPROPRIATE RESPONSE SHEET AND DISPOSAL FLOW CHART.

item.title: Report E-2024090406
item.description:

  • City: WESTLAND
  • State: MI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: An spill occurred at Veolia's ten-day transit facility located in Westland, MI during a routine drum transfer operation. An employee was using a drum picker to load a drum onto a trailer when the situation occurred. As the drum was being maneuvered into position, it inadvertently made contact with the side of the trailer. Upon impact, it was discovered that a sharp piece of metal protruding from the trailer's side had punctured the drum, resulting in a dime-sized hole. The employee immediately noticed the damage and the subsequent leak. It was estimated that approximately two gallons of the drum's contents had spilled as a result of the puncture.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-09-22T09:13:18+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-09-09
  • City: SANTA ROSA BEACH
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On September 9, 2024, five (5) five-gallon pails of primer were dropped during unloading and released approximately twenty (20) gallons of primer to the asphalt. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from NRC Gulf Environmental Services, Inc. (NRC Gulf) to remediate the impacted site. NRC Gulf placed all damaged pails into seven (7) lined 55-gallon drums. Granular absorbents were placed onto all primer impacted areas. The crew swept up all loose absorbents with hand tools. A pressure washing system was used on all stained concrete and a vac truck was utilized to retain any loose water. All seven (7) waste drums were taken offsite and staged at the Milton, Florida R+L terminal. All waste water was taken with the crew to be disposed of on a later date.

  • City: ELLENWOOD
  • State: GA

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On September 9, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN2265 was shipped with faulty packaging and released approximately ten (10) gallons of product to the dock floor and pallet below. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the impacted site. HES personnel utilized absorbents to remediate the dock floor and impacted pallet. Crews collected the 55-gallon drum into one (1) 95-gallon drum. All spent absorbent media were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum for CES processing.

item.title: Report E-2024090414
item.description:
Report E-2024090414

Identified by scraper @ 2024-09-22T09:13:18+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-09-09
  • City: AKRON
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On September 9, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of organic peroxide had a damaged cap and released approximately two (2) ounces to the top of the drum. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. FCE personnel deployed absorbent rags to the impacted drum, and neutralized the exterior. A replacement cap was then used to fix the drum. The drum was staged on the truck for future shipping. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon vented drum and was taken to the Columbiana terminal for future disposal.

  • Description: At 1204 ET, XPO terminal UMV notified ERTS of a cargo release. It was reported that approximately 1-Quart of Premier 6 PH-18 HS Urethane Activator medium released due to unknown reasons. The release impacted trailer #3178599. No storm drains or waterways are reported to be impacted by the release. ERTS reviewed the SDS with the caller and determined that terminal personnel are capable of cleaning the release with PPE available on site. The terminal used oil dri to absorb the spill and a 5-Gallon metal drum for the waste. The waste was staged on site for terminal personnel to manage.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-09-22T09:13:18+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-20
  • City: INDIANAPOLIS
  • State: IN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: US ECOLOGY TRANSPORTATION SOLUTIONS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: The bottle of nitric acid was packed in accordance with lab pack standards and shipped to the 10-day transfer facility in Indianapolis. The package was transferred onto an on-site trailer at the facility and placed on top of a 5-gallon pail unsecured. When the trailer was subsequently moved into the dock, the lab pack box fell 18 inches and approximately 1/2 quart of nitric acid leaked from the package. The original container and the clean up residue were overpacked in a 15-gallon poly drum with vermiculite. The containers were not fully blocked and braced since the trailer was not leaving the site.

  • Description: Driver was unloading Sulfuric at GlobITech Sherman TX dry mate broke on the fill line to tank as the driver was offloading sulfuric acid. There was a 200ft hose and Globitech employee assisting with transfer. The PVC line broke spilling<10 gallons of material into containment. The material splashed on the Globitech employee burning him on his back. He was rinsed in the EW.SS and went to the hospital. He was released the same day and made a full recovery.

item.title: Report X-2024070285
item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-09-21T00:40:08+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-17
  • City: MCRAE
  • State: AR
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNION PACIFIC RAILROAD COMPANY INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 45
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 50000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Car was found releasing vapor as it went through Beebe, AR and was stopped by the local FD outside McRae, AR. The FD conducted a 1/2-mile evacuation and isolated the area. Upon HMM arrival, we met with the FD and was granted approval to access the car. Upon inspection of the car, liquid was observed releasing from under the valve at the connection of the 4-bolt valve flange to the flanged riser due to all four nuts that secure the valve to the flange not secured. The four nuts were found inside the protective housing. The pressure was removed from the car, the leak stopped, and the four bolts properly secured. The car was neutralized and set out. An OTMA-1 was granted for movement back to the shipper.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LEP experienced a UN1866 Bulldog Adhesion Promoter release from 2 boxes each containing (6) 1-quart metal bottles. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 6 quarts of product released to a 3’ x 5’ area of the trailer floor and a 3’ x 4’ area of the concrete lot below. The cans were damaged as a result of being crushed due to stacking/improper loading. The (8) damaged cans were placed into a 55-gallon metal drum. All impacted cardboard, pads, and absorbents used to clean the spill were placed into a second 55-gallon metal drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 9/13/2024 at approximately 2330, Dnagerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 220288 at the hub facility in Memphis, reporting a dangerous goods spill. The shipment consisted of 30 small cans of paint packaged in a fiberboard box. One of the can had a loose top, resulting in spillage. The shipment was placed in a salvage drum and awaits an amended Shipper's declaration for further transport.

item.title: Report E-2024090347
item.description:
Report E-2024090347

Identified by scraper @ 2024-09-19T09:21:33+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-09-13
  • City: DALLAS
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS FREIGHT, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO-Logistics contacted ERTS regarding a punctured bottle of hazardous product, Instant Power® Heavy Duty Drain Opener. The plastic bottle was punctured by a forklift blade that resulted in the release of approximately 1-gallon of product onto the pallet and wooden trailer floor in an 8’x2’ area. A Contractor neutralized the release using KolorSafe Liquid Neutralizer and applied oil dry. The neutralized impacted pallet was cut-up and containerized into a 95-gallon DF. The neutralized impacted absorbents, PPE, and product were containerized into a 55-gallon DF. XPO will manage the waste until end disposal. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were involved in this incident.

  • Incident Date: 2024-09-13
  • City: TYLER
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: There were 8 boxes in the shipment each containing 4 cans. One of the boxes appears to have been crushed by freight in transit before arriving to service center 177, but the damage went unnoticed to the customer facility. The customer refused 5 of the 8 boxes due to the damaged can leaking onto the other boxes. It was then noticed that service center 070 noted that the shipment was damaged but did not note the type of damage and sent it on to 177. CURA was contacted for remediation.

  • Description: On 9/12/2024 at approximately 1830, Dangerous Goods Administration was notified that a package, classified as UN 3373, shipping under Tracking # 777754911170 was discovered leaking at the ramp facility in Flint, MI. The package was discovered in a documents bag, displaying dampness. The eOps report indicates that the shipment was originally retrieved from a local drop box; however, the cause of the spillage cannot be confirmed. No other packages were affected, as the spillage appeared to be contained inside the documents bag. The spilled package was placed is a salvage drum for proper disposal.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On September 6, 2024, one (1) 5-gallon pail of Swisher Hercules was punctured and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. FCE personnel deployed granular absorbents to the Swisher Hercules-impacted dock floor and swept them in with hand tools. Crews neutralized the absorbents and spilled materials and utilized pH test strips. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum, and one (1) damaged pail of Swisher Hercules was collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum.

Contractors arrived on site and confirmed 3-gallons of UN1263 "DURANAR BONE WHITE" product released to 3'x3' area of the trailer floor due to improper loading. Contractors deployed absorbents to the impacted area. The damaged drum was overpacked into a 95-gallon poly waste drum. All impacted absorbents were containerized into a 55-gallon metal drum. The waste was transported to the XPO terminal located in Amarillo, TX for terminal personnel to manage. The waste was staged on site for terminal personnel to manage.

ERTS dispatched a contractor to the site to complete cleanup activities. Contractors arrived on site, neutralized the area, deployed absorbents, and cleaned up the released material from 2'x23' trailer and 2'x10 concrete with impacted acid pads and Sodium Baicarb. Product was transloaded to new metal tote. Damaged tote and drum were staged onsite at the terminal for personnel to manage.

item.title: Report I-2024070152
item.description:
Report I-2024070152

Identified by scraper @ 2024-09-19T00:40:34+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-30
  • City: SAN BERNARDINO
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: BNSF RAILWAY COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Sequence of Events: On 6/27/2024, the Pressurizer was picked up by BNSF and arrived in Stuart Railyard in Oceanside, California (same day). On 6/30/2024, Pressurizer arrived at the San Bernardino Railyard in California where the leak was discovered by the BNSF rail inspector. On 7/4/2024, Pressurizer transported back to the SONGS Site for repair. Actions Taken at the time it was discovered: Site Emergency Response Team initiated per site procedures. Leak was stopped with the use of JB Weld & Silicon Sealant. Package Failure (including the size and location of holes, cracks, etc.): Manway cover and other sealed openings not completely sealed. Estimate the duration of the release: Two days (very slow leak, approximately <3 liters overall). Mitigation actions (effects of the release): Site investigation identified gaps in the development and implementation of the work package in that no guidance to remediate residual liquids nor re-inspect the pressurizer once it was placed into its shipping configuration to validate residual liquids was still in the pressurizer.

  • Description: Andrew Pinedo, 042 Operations Supervisor, contacted Safety regarding a drum leaking from the nozzle. Andrew Pinedo stated the leak was noticed while unloading the trailer. Andrew Pinedo advised the seal or the nozzle was damaged in transit. Andrew Pinedo requested straight time remediation due to th e leak being contained to the lid of the drum. Andrew Pinedo advised moving the drum from Bay 139 to OSD for the spill team. Alex VerHagen with Cura was contacted for remediation on straight time.

  • City: CONNERSVILLE

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: When unloading totes of material it was noticed that their was a slight drip coming from the weld on one of the legs of the tote. It was a very slight leak and nothing spilled onto the truck. The tote was put onto a spill skid and the spot in the warehouse where the tote sat was cleaned up in house. We think from repeated transport of the tote that a weak spot was made in the weld of the body with the leg. Tote will be scrapped.

  • Incident Date: 2024-09-13
  • City: NITRO
  • State: WV
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Ellen Crislip, 252 Operations Supervisor, contacted Safety regarding a UN1760 spill to the dock floor. Ellen Crislip advised Safety that while Steve Looney, dock worker, was unloading the freight one box was punctured by the forklift. Ellen Crislip stated a piece of the wood on the pallet broke caus ing the box to fall below the pallet resulting in the box being punctured. Ellen Crislip advised they placed pads down to soak the spill and the box is now upright not leaking. Ellen Crislip stated the dock worker was attempting to clean the spill in house. Safety directed Ellen Crislip to stop the dock worker. Safety stated Cura would need to be contacted for remediation. Ellen Crislip advised Cura to be contacted on straight time since the spill is contained. ~

item.title: Report X-2024090936
item.description:
Report X-2024090936

Identified by scraper @ 2024-09-18T09:15:04+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-09-12
  • City: LOUISVILLE
  • State: KY
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AT THE UPS WORLDPORT FACILITY IN LOUISVILLE, KENTUCKY, ONE AIR PACKAGE WAS INSPECTED DUE TO A LABEL ON THE BOX STATING, "BATTERY INSIDE". UPON INSPECTION OF THE CONTENTS DISCOVERED FOUR LENOVO THINKPADS. TWO OF THE THINKPADS WERE PACKAGED INSIDE LAPTOP BAGS. TWO OF THE THINKPADS WERE PACKED INSIDE THE BOX IN USPS PAD PACKS. THE PACKAGE ALSO CONTAINED TWO LAPTOP CHARGERS AND A LENOVO LAPTOP DOCK. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX.

  • Description: On September 6th during the PM sort a box was found that was wet and was compromised. The inside packages were viewable from the water damage and there were two packages inside of the outer package both of them marked as Class 2.2 and Class 5.1 and contained UN1070, Nitrous Oxide, 2.2(5.1). There were no markings on the outside of the outer package to indicate dangerous goods were inside. The packge has been placed inside of a steel salvage drum and is being held pending disposition.

item.title: Report E-2024090318
item.description:
Report E-2024090318

Identified by scraper @ 2024-09-18T09:15:04+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-09-05
  • City: MATTESON
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On September 5, 2024, one (1) 1-gallon pail of uN1824 was crushed in transit and released approximately one-half (0.5) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from HazChem Environmental (HCE) to remediate the impacted site. HCE deployed a bicarbonate/water mixture to the trailer floor to neutralize the product. Granular absorbents were deployed to retrieve all loose product, as well as the bicarbonate/water mixture. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum, The damaged product container was placed into one (1) 5-gallon drum.

  • City: OAK CREEK
  • State: WI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AT THE UPS FACILITY IN OAK CREEK, WISCONSIN, ONE FULLY MARKED AND LABELED DANGEROUS GOODS PACKAGE WAS FOUND LEAKING DURING THE TRAILER UNLOAD. DANGEROUS GOODS SHIPPING PAPERS WERE APPLIED TO THE PACKAGE AND HAD PASSED AN ACCEPTANCE AUDIT AT THE ORIGIN FACILITY IN MICHIGAN. THE PACKAGE CONTAINED SIX X ONE LITER BOTTLES OF VIO NEXUS ANTISEPTIC HAND SANITIZER. ONE BOTTLE WAS LEAKING APPROXIMATLY TEN OUNCES FROM A LOOSE CLOSURE. NO PHOTOS WERE OBTAINED OF THE LEAKING PACKAGE.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-09-18T09:15:04+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-22
  • City: WALBRIDGE
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 8/22/2024, at 1353 hours, CSXT personnel at the Walbridge Yard discovered FHRX135943, a loaded tank car of Sulfur, Molten, with a vapor release from the connection between the manway nozzle and the manway cover. The car was isolated and the shipper, Marathon Petroleum Company, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report #2024082200196). CSXT Hazardous Materials Manager Scott Karcher found the manway gasket to be improperly installed (misaligned) which allowed for a vapor release. The damaged gasket was removed, a new gasket was installed, and the manway was secured for transportation. The issue was identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper’s representative (Jennifer Johnson 209-986-1196). This incident did require a special switching move. 7.1 is not required.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 55000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 1350 ET, Jeremiah Faustinos with XPO terminal UPH notified ERTS of a cargo release. It was reported that an estimated amount of 2-Gallons of UN3103 Organic Peroxide Type C released due to pressurizing during transit. The release impacted trailer #3233003. No storm drains or waterways are reported to be impacted by the release. ERTS dispatched a contractor to perform cleanup activities. Contractors arrived on site and confirmed approximately 50 gallons of product released to 15'x8.5' area of the trailer floor due to excessive heat. Contractors transferred product, empty jerricans, impacted absorbents to 3 drums, 4 totes and 10 CUYD's. The waste was staged on site for terminal personnel to manage. All liquid product was salvaged and transferred into poly jerricans and sent on to customer.

  • Description: At 18:12 EST on 8/21, XPO-UPH contacted ERTS to report a spill of about 4 ounces of UN1993 "Unisol Liquid Red BK-50" from a 250-gallon metal tote impacting the trailer floor. The tote was discovered with a crack in the body at the bottom of the tote, which was likely damaged during loading at XCN. ERTS dispatched a contractor to assist with cleaning the spill and transferring the remaining liquid to a new tote. The salvage material and leaking tote was transferred into drums for salvage. Contractors arrived on site and confirmed approximately 4 ounces of product impacted the trailer floor due to faulty weld/seam on tote leg. Contractors then containerized to 1 55-gallon drum. The waste was staged on site for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 2500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 1558ET, XPO notified ERTS of a cargo release located at terminal USA in Sacramento, CA. It was reported that approximately 1 ounce of UN1760 SHINELINE EMULSIFIER PLUS released from (1) carton containing (4) 1-gallon jugs of product due to the box being crushed by the boxes stacked on top of it. The release impacted the trailer floor, the pallet, and a second carton. ERTS reviewed the SDS and determined that a contractor is necessary due to the corrosivity (Class 8). ERTS dispatched a contractor to perform cleanup activities. Contractors arrived on site and confirmed approximately 1 ounce of product released to 2'x2' area of the trailer floor due to improper loading. Contractors deployed absorbents and sodium bicarb solution to the impacted area to clean and neutralize the release. The damaged bottle impacted cardboard and cleanup debris were containerized to 2–55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged on site for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 1500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Covered hopper car CRDX 970231, loaded with ammonium nitrate prills, was found at Spencer Yard with a failure of the car body during an outbound mechanical inspection. At some point, the car body crumpled and a small tear opened along a bend resulting in approximately 2 pound of ammonium nitrate releasing from the car. An investigation was conducted into the cause of the car failure and no incidents of rough handling or impacts were found. The car arrived at Spencer Yard and was not flat switched while at the yard but moved as a block of cars to an outbound track where the damage was found. The car passed an outbound mechanical inspection at the previous station in Columbia, SC where the car was last switched.

  • City: ROANOKE

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal NRO experienced an approximate ten (10) gallons release of UN1760 Hydroco BT-78 from one (1) 20-gallon poly drum impacting the trailer floor and asphalt underneath the trailer. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 45'X1' area of the trailer floor and a 10'x2' area of the asphalt underneath the trailer. An estimated ten (10) gallons of material was released due to a pallet nail puncture. Contractors overpacked the two drums, neutralized the area, deployed absorbents, and cleaned up the released material. The damaged drum, impacted drum, and recovered material were placed into three (3) 55-gallon poly drums and was staged onsite at the terminal prior to the contractor demobilization.

item.title: Report E-2024090301
item.description:
Report E-2024090301

Identified by scraper @ 2024-09-18T09:15:04+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-14
  • City: OSCEOLA
  • State: AR
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 27000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LJB experienced a customer location and roadside release of UN1819 Xcelerator A38 from a 300-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 110-gallons of product released to a 53' x 8' area of the trailer floor, 54' x 8' area of the asphalt roadway, a 54' x 2.5' area of the soil shoulder, and a 30' x 40' area of the customer’s asphalt lot as well as into a storm drain catch basin. Contractors secured the release with absorbents, pads, and boom upon arrival. The crew confirmed the tote was punctured due to improper loading. The material still in the damaged tote was transferred into a new one. Once all free liquid was absorbed, sodium bicarbonate and water were used to rinse the impacted areas to clean and neutralize them. The following day, the crew returned to site with a vac truck and a pressure washer. The impacted catch basin was vacuumed and flushed out. The customer confirmed the pumps were shut off so the material could not migrate from the drains catch basin. The impacted concrete lot at the customers location and the impacted asphalt roadway were then pressure washed, and all material was collected into a vac-truck. Approximately 1300-gallons of impacted wastewater were removed from site pending disposal. (5) 55-gallon poly drums of impacted absorbents, the cut up damaged poly tote, and impacted debris were transported to the XPO Terminal located in Jonesboro, AR for terminal personnel to manage. The impacted soil shoulder was then secured and marked for future remediation.
